I was a young caseworker at the adult aftercare agency, John Howard Society, in Montreal from 1969 to 1974. When Puzo's book came out, we devoured it admiring it almost as a sociological treatise on the principal of "social reciprocity" in traditional organized crime groups. When the movie came out a mere three years later, we saw it all there again when the Don held court at the wedding handing out "favors" which would be ruthlessly called in later. One of our missions in rehabilitating offenders was to show them that they could receive and give favors without getting or giving anything in return except a "thank you" in normal society. The "pay it forward" notion caught on. 
The irreconcilable clash of social values was most vividly captured by Michael's (Al Pacino) need to lie to Kay (Diane Keaton) about the nature of the business so he would not lose her. This was an essential  representation of how women were manipulated and not considered "equals" in the crime family mentality. 
The on-screen violence was a necessary metaphor about the perversion of personal morality in gangster life brought to its ultimate climax when Sonny is killed and more vividly in the third movie when Michael's innocent daughter is slaughtered.
The Godfather is a film for the ages that is a mesmerizing morality tale as well as a historical "snapshot" of a sub strata of society in a bygone time.

What does The Godfather do well?  Several things.  

First, it clearly defines the characters.  Don Vito Corleone is a man of power and renown.  He has worked tirelessly to build his business and demands loyalty and respect. The camera work and lighting is excellent - alternating between close ups of the characters faces and long shots of scenery or key moments involving cars.  Dark and light are used to show the slow transition of Michael's personality/soul through the movie.  

The quotes are numerous and memorable.  My favorite, "leave the gun...take the cannoli".

So many iconic/shocking scenes - do I need to say more than the blood soaked bed of the movie producer?

The movie touches on a variety of topics - family, business, rivalries, money, prestige, power, influence, arrogance, intelligence, pride, distrust, betrayal, vengeance, ascension, decline, age, murder, and ultimately good vs. evil.  

I have seen the movie several times and appreciate different elements.  The musical theme is very memorable and captures the mood - sorrowful, heavy, emotional.

The Godfather is unquestionably a good film; good cinematography, plot, acting and score. But is it really as great as is implied? I feel the same way about The Godfather as Citizen Kane and i've watched both a few times. 

There is only so much a mob movie can offer. Can we really empathize with the characters, who essentially are high-level criminals? Does it offer something for everyone? I feel a lot of people jump on the bandwagon without thinking this through. And what is the message of the film? Being a loyal 'made man' is some sort of redemption? That there is something noble about a life of crime and 'not ratting' ? That if you cross a dangerous don you get a horses head in your bed? That is how I feel about all mob films - no matter how good the direction, acting and cinematography, ultimately they are glorifying high level criminals as some sort of Robin Hood-like figures. And the Godfather arguably started this unhealthy message. 

Is being 'well-made' enough to be considered 'the greatest film ever' ?  

The Godfather is a good film - probably a great film but there is no way it is the greatest film ever made as it is so often hyped up to be. Even in the mob genre, I would say there are others that are close to the caliber of the Godfather and not as distant as some make out. A Bronx Tale for example. Brando's drawling performance was good but it, like the film, has been very overhyped. And even by 70s standards, the pace can seem slow at points. 

Some might say giving this 3/5 is a sort of blasphemy but for all the above reasons that is what I am giving it. If I was rating it out of 10 - perhaps a strong 7 but not higher. All in all I just think there are less appreciated films that are at least as good as The Godfather. 

As Peter Griffin of Family Guy said 'it insists upon itself' and in a way it does - ie a lot of people go to the template of it's greatness without really explaining why.

There is a subtle oversimplification of the difference in family dynamics in the context of the rich vis-à-vis the poor. The poor family is more commonly viewed as being more tightly bound to one another, as a family is all that there is to value. On the other hand, the rich family is often regarded as detached for their wealth keeps them apart, a rather opportune to indulgence in luxury and vices.

The film, however, disproves this conception and shows that the rich can honor their familial relationships, as the central theme of the story follows the Corleone family.

The Corleones, a part of the syndicate that conducts “dirty” businesses, dwells on liquor and gambling. Along their venture, they inevitably grow into conflict with other families as well, this being a mere part of business. Aggrandizing criminals as they may appear, the grounds for the wars among these families are, from the outset, deeply rooted in personal feuds.

It is a war over which family is the most powerful, in which victory is sustained by how power is derived—coercion or loyalty. Power derived in coercion crumbles in a dispute, whereas power derived in loyalty endures and triumphs.
